utterances: You could see the smoke?

How do you think an experience like this, such a huge trauma in a small town, how does it mark the town even this long after the fact?
Well, anywhere you go, most people that you talk to has heard of the Number Nine disaster.
To have that many people killed at one time is a traumatic experience.
You mentioned the memorial that's held every year.
Do you feel the impact of what happened back in 1968 throughout the year?
Are there other times when it comes back to you?
Definitely, yeah.
I personally am 61 years old, but you think back, that that was when my beginning a family was starting.
I had two daughters, a year and two years old.
We struggled for employment for a while; it was a hard thing that way.
Hmm.
And it was during the holiday season.
The whole area was kind of in a state of mind of, `Are they going to find any more alive, or are they going to seal the mines?
And I can remember the big controversy.
There was really not a fix for the situation at the time, and there isn't now.
And a lot of the laws made for mining was enacted because of what happened at that mine.
I've read that there were widows of some of the miners who were killed who went to testify before Congress, and that's what ultimately led to, in 1969, the Coal Mine Safety and Health Act.
Some of them have been critically acclaimed, and I think that's part of the problem here.
One picture did a lot of business, ""The Kingdom."" It's a straight-ahead war movie.

The rest of them have been different.
Lions for Lambs"" is really an argument about war policy, and it's done about $11 million so far.

Rendition,"" which is about sending someone overseas to be interrogated there has made about $9 million.
So next to those, ""The Kingdom"" at $47 million looks like a big hit.

This is not ""Spiderman."" Note as to how many people that means.
$11 million is probably two million people, okay?
So two million people went to see ""Lions for Lambs."" That's not bad, but it's not in the same league as most Tom Cruise movies.
What's motivating the directors and the studios to take on these subjects?
Well, I think everybody expects Hollywood to deal with tough issues.
And I, you know, they do it all the time and frequently in pictures that win Oscars.
So I think the hope is that not only can you, sort of, put your feelings out there about all of these - and that's what movies really are about.
They're about feelings.
They're not about policy.
It's not a good place to debate policy for the most part, but it is a good place to get the emotions out there.

Now, I asked, you know, what's motivating the studio and the directors because it's interesting, if you look back to the late '60s, early '70s and these very successful films about the Vietnam War experience.
They were not contemporaneous.
They were released.
A lot of those successful movies were released…
That's right.
…long after…
Yeah, five or six years later.
…the soldiers had come home.
Yeah.
Or the ones that we remember, things like ""Apocalypse Now"" and ""Platoon"" and ""Deer Hunter,"" all of which came out later.
And if you think about the picture that came out during the war, when we were actually prosecuting the war in Vietnam, the big one was ""The Green Berets,"" and that's a John Wayne movie.
(Soundbite of movie ""The Green Berets"")
What would happen to me now?
(As Colonel Mike Kirby) You let me worry about that green beret.
You're what this is all about.
And it's, you know, I mean, it's very gung ho.
It's about taking care of the situation over there because we're America and we're going to do that.

And I think during the war in Vietnam, if you had questioned the motives of all of these, people who remembered World War II and how war movies went back then would have thought you were aiding and abetting the enemy.
I think we're in a different place now.
So, what led to the - if we can just look back, when did those gates start to open up when we you the ""Deer Hunter,"" ""Apocalypse Now"" coming home?
Well, that was - it was actually the late 1970s.
So it was well after our part in the fighting in Vietnam had ended.
And a lot of people were back and were sort of deconstructing what had happened.
There were a lot of veterans who would come back and who were clearly not happy.
And there was a lot of feeling about what had happened and trying to get your head around it.
I think what's interesting about this particular push right now is that we're trying to get our heads around it while it's still going on.
Hollywood is grappling with the issues, and what they're - what they seem to be doing mostly is to deal with the fact that these are complex issues, that this is not easy answer stuff.
That's kind of adventuresome and bold in a way, but it is also the kind of thing that leads to a picture that is not necessarily satisfying in the sense that we - that Hollywood has led us to expect.

And again, you know, looking back, it seems that Hollywood was sort of working through those issues, at least with regard to Vietnam for several years, because if you, sort of, reach beyond the late 1970s and the '80s, you then saw ""Platoon"" and ""Full Metal Jacket"" and older films.

The Kite Runner,"" which is about Afghanistan and rescuing children from the Taliban.
